summary: Project scope shifts from a construction-themed truck/JCB Android game to creating a "Free Fire India" style game and launching it on the Google Play Store.
architectural_notes: Current build is a mobile web game; to be installable via Play Store it must be wrapped/packaged as an Android app (e.g., WebView/Cordova/Capacitor or Trusted Web Activity) and released as AAB/APK.
Release/hosting pipeline requires a valid domain/app identifier slug (5–50 characters; only letters, numbers, hyphens; no spaces or symbols like '+').

Game scope now includes additional thematic content (construction vehicles, police, mafia conflict) and may require more complex gameplay systems than the original simple driving/avoid-obstacles loop.
known_issues: Build/packaging attempt failed with error: "Unable to create your app" (needs investigation in the build/release pipeline).
User attempted invalid domain names causing validation errors (spaces/symbols/length).

existing_features.title: Implement a simple, mobile-friendly truck game playable in a mobile browser on Android phones (responsive layout, touch-first controls, works in portrait and landscape).

Create core gameplay loop: a truck driving forward on a road with simple steering (left/right) to avoid obstacles; include a score that increases over time (or by distance) and a game-over state on collision.
Add basic game screens and controls: Start screen (Play), in-game Pause/Resume, and Game Over screen with Restart.
Provide a coherent visual theme (colors, typography, UI styling) suitable for a casual truck game and apply it consistently across menus, HUD, and buttons (avoid default/un-styled UI).

Add Progressive Web App (PWA) support so the truck game can be installed on Android from the browser (Add to Home screen / Install app), including a valid web app manifest, service worker for offline caching, and required icon assets wiring.
Add an in-app English help/instructions section on the Start screen explaining how to install the game on Android using the browser (e.g., Chrome menu → “Install app” / “Add to Home screen”).

Add a new "Publish on Google Play" help section (English) on the Start screen that explains that the current game is a web/PWA app, and outlines the high-level steps to publish it to the Google Play Store (e.g., wrap the PWA as an Android app using Trusted Web Activity, create an AAB, upload to Play Console).

Add a repository documentation file that provides a practical, step-by-step checklist for publishing this PWA to the Google Play Store, including: required Play Console items (app listing, screenshots, feature graphic), generating Android wrapper (TWA), creating/signing AAB, Digital Asset Links (assetlinks.json) hosting expectations, testing, and common troubleshooting for release/publishing.

Ensure the app has the required PWA metadata suitable for packaging/publishing: confirm a web app manifest is present and linked from the HTML entrypoint, includes correct name/short_name, start_url, display, theme/background colors, and includes required icon sizes. If any of these are missing, add/update them and make sure the app still runs normally in the browser.

Upgrade the game’s visual fidelity to a higher-graphics construction theme (colors, UI surfaces, typography, overlays, and in-game visuals) while keeping the existing mobile-first controls and screen flow (Start, Play, Pause, Game Over).

Add construction-themed gameplay content featuring both a truck and a JCB (excavator/backhoe) within the running game loop (e.g., as player vehicle + construction vehicles/props in the scene), using new high-graphics art assets rather than simple geometric placeholders.
Add a visible 'DUMFFER Police' element integrated into the construction setting/gameplay (as a character/vehicle/signage), with all user-facing text in English.

Add a simple, non-graphic 'big mafia vs small mafia' fight/conflict gameplay element that can occur during runs (e.g., as a special obstacle/event to avoid or navigate), keeping the game appropriate for a broad audience and avoiding explicit gore.

Ensure the app is ready for Android install and Play Store packaging by selecting and applying a valid, Play-Store-friendly app identifier/domain slug (5–50 chars, letters/numbers/hyphens only) consistently wherever required in the PWA configuration and Play Store publishing documentation.
Add the new generated high-graphics art assets to the frontend as static files and wire them into the gameplay UI (do not serve generated images from the backend).

Replace any use of the name "Free Fire" / "Free Fire India" with an original game name and branding throughout the app (UI copy, metadata, docs) to avoid using third-party/trademarked IP; keep all user-facing text in English.

Update PWA/app identity metadata to match the new original game name, including: frontend/public/manifest.webmanifest (id/name/short_name/description/theme/background colors if needed) and frontend/index.html (title/meta description/theme-color/icons references).

Implement a simple, mobile-friendly "battle royale style" game loop (single-player) suitable for Android browsers: on-screen touch controls, a player character that moves/aims, enemies/bots that spawn, a safe non-graphic combat mechanic (e.g., tap-to-shoot or auto-shoot), health, score/kills, and clear Win/Lose conditions, with Start/Pause/Game Over flow preserved.

Replace the current construction-truck gameplay UI assets usage in the game scene with new, original battle-game art assets stored as static files under frontend/public/assets/generated, and wire them into the new game (do not serve images from the backend).
Update Google Play publishing documentation (frontend/docs/PLAY_STORE_PUBLISHING.md) so it reflects the new original game name, identifier, and required listing assets/screenshots for the new game.
